title: The rise and fall of the medieval Islamic Empire - Petra Sijpesteijn & Birte Kristiansen

multiple-choice.question: Who united the people of the Arabian Peninsula through the formation of Islam in the 7th century CE?

Who succeeded Muhammad as the new caliph after his death?
What was the name of the dynasty that came to power after the fourth caliph, Ali, was assassinated?
What language was used as the administrative language to unify political affairs across the Islamic Empire?

What was the result of the extensive trade networks established under Abbasid rule?

options.label: A
options.text: A decline in artistic and scientific advancements

options.label: B
options.text: A decrease in the caliph's wealth and power

options.label: C
options.text: A lifestyle of luxury for the elite

options.label: D
options.text: A clear line of succession for the caliph

options.label: A
options.text: A unified empire under one ruler

options.label: B
options.text: A decline in artistic and scientific advancements

options.label: C
options.text: A lasting mark through written and spoken Arabic, Islam, and the ideas of its greatest intellectuals

title: Can you guess what's wrong with these paintings? - Noah Charney

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The painting was from the 19th century and had undergone restoration.

options.label: D
options.text: The painting was from the 20th century and had been altered.

multiple-choice.question: What technology was used to discover the countenance of a completely different woman under the outer surface of the painting?

options.label: B
options.text: Heavy-handed approach to improve the art

options.label: C
options.text: Focus on removing old varnish to reveal the original colors

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To remove old paint layers and reveal the original work

options.label: D
options.text: To add new details to the painting

options.label: A
options.text: To restore the original colors and details

options.label: B
options.text: To boost sales because the original subject wasn't considered attractive

options.label: C
options.text: To remove old varnish and reveal the original work

options.label: D
options.text: To add new details to the painting

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: It was damaged by acid and stabbing

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: How were the missing pieces of "The Night Watch" replaced in the 2019 conservation project?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: By using another artist's rendering of the original

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B

title: A brief history of Spanish - Ilan Stavans

multiple-choice.question: In what century did the Romans conquer the Iberian Peninsula, giving rise to regional languages such as Castilian, Catalan, and Galician?

From which Indigenous language did words with "ch" and "y" like "chapulin" and "coyote" become part of Spanish?

title: Why a sausage can do what your gloves cannot - Charles Wallace and Sajan Saini

multiple-choice.question: In 2010, South Korea experienced a particularly cold winter, leading to an unusual trend involving snack sausages. What was the reason behind this trend?

options.label: A
options.text: People were using sausages as a substitute for smartphones.

options.label: B
options.text: Sausages were being used as a means to activate smartphones while wearing gloves.

options.label: C
options.text: People were eating more sausages due to the cold weather.

options.label: D
options.text: Sausages were being used as a makeshift heating source.

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary reason for the development of the first touchscreen in 1965?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a more user-friendly interface for smartphones.

options.label: B
options.text: To help British air traffic controllers efficiently update flight plans.

options.label: C
options.text: To develop a new type of computer monitor.

options.label: D
options.text: To create a more durable type of screen.

multiple-choice.question: What type of touchscreen dominated the market before the release of the iPhone in 2007?
What is the primary principle behind the functioning of a capacitive touchscreen?
What is the main difference between a conductor and an insulator?

options.label: A
options.text: Conductors are more expensive than insulators.

options.label: B
options.text: Conductors are more durable than insulators.

options.label: C
options.text: Conductors allow electrons to flow easily, while insulators do not.

options.label: D
options.text: Conductors are less common than insulators.

multiple-choice.question: How do resistive touchscreens work?

options.label: A
options.text: By using a grid of conductive lines to detect touch.

options.label: B
options.text: By using a single layer of conductive material to detect touch.

options.label: C
options.text: By connecting two layers of conductive material to complete an electric circuit.

options.label: D
options.text: By using a camera to detect touch.

multiple-choice.question: Why are capacitive touchscreens generally easier to use than resistive touchscreens?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they require more force to activate.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they interact directly with the user's finger without the application of force.

multiple-choice.question: Why can objects like banana peels and certain processed meats activate a capacitive touchscreen?
What happens when water is splashed across a capacitive touchscreen?

options.label: C
options.text: The screen may trigger multiple underlying nodes, causing the phone to act like it's being touched in multiple places at once.

multiple-choice.question: Why do gloves interfere with the use of a capacitive touchscreen?

title: This weird trick will help you summon an army of worms - Kenny Coogan

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the process of luring earthworms out of the ground using a metal strip and a wooden stake?
Where is the Apalachicola National Forest located?

options.label: A
options.text: The noise charms them like the rats from the medieval Pied Piper legend.

options.label: B
options.text: The vibrations from the grunting tickle their bodies.

options.label: C
options.text: The grunting mimics falling rain and the worms flee to avoid drowning.

multiple-choice.question: Who tested the hypothesis that worm grunting mimics falling rain?

options.label: A
options.text: Most of the earthworms emerged from the ground.

options.label: B
options.text: Only two earthworms emerged from the ground.

options.label: C
options.text: The earthworms burrowed deeper into the ground.

options.label: D
options.text: The earthworms did not respond to the grunting.

options.label: B
options.text: "The Formation of Vegetable Mould, Through the Action of Worms, with Observations on their Habits"

options.label: D
options.text: "The Expression of Emotions in Man and Animals"

multiple-choice.question: According to Charles Darwin, why might earthworms flee their burrows when the ground trembles?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: They're trying to escape the vibrations.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Kenneth Catania's experiment testing the hypothesis that earthworms flee their burrows because they believe they're being pursued by moles?

options.label: A
options.text: The earthworms did not respond to the presence of the mole.

options.label: B
options.text: About 30% of the earthworms crawled to the surface in the first hour.

options.label: C
options.text: The earthworms burrowed deeper into the ground.

multiple-choice.question: Why do scientists think the earthworms' behavior of fleeing their burrows when they believe they're being pursued by moles persists despite making them vulnerable to other predators?

options.label: A
options.text: It's beneficial for a prey species to maintain its adaptations against a more frequent predator.

options.label: B
options.text: It's a result of genetic drift.

options.label: C
options.text: It's a result of natural selection.

title: The 4 greatest threats to the survival of humanity

options.label: B
options.text: A massive asteroid heading towards Earth

options.label: C
options.text: A nuclear missile from the United States

options.label: D
options.text: A cyber attack on Russia's defense system

What is the next major addition to human existential risk after nuclear weapons?

options.label: A
options.text: A moderate increase in sea levels

options.label: B
options.text: A significant decrease in global food production

options.label: C
options.text: A calamity of possibly unprecedented proportions

options.label: D
options.text: A complete halt in global economic growth

options.label: D

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: Treating safeguarding humanity's future as the defining issue of our time

title: The world’s slimiest animal - Noah R. Bressman and Douglas Fudge

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the 2017 car accident involving a truck carrying live hagfish?

options.label: B
options.text: The highway was littered with wriggling fish and coated in a thick slime.

options.label: C
options.text: The truck driver was injured and taken to the hospital.

options.label: D
options.text: The accident caused a massive fire that took hours to extinguish.

multiple-choice.question: What is the standout strength of all hagfish?

options.label: A
options.text: Their sharp teeth and powerful jaws.

options.label: B
options.text: Their ability to swim at high speeds.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Using their keen sense of smell and tastebud-like organs on their skin.

options.label: C
options.text: Using their powerful jaws to search for food.

options.label: D

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: How do hagfish remove their own slime from their bodies?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: By tying themselves in a knot to wipe it away.

options.label: C
options.text: By using their sharp teeth to scrape it off.

options.label: D

options.text: For their potential use as a sustainable alternative to petroleum-based fibers.

options.label: C
options.text: For their potential use in food production.

options.label: D
options.text: For their potential use in construction materials.

title: What’s the best country to live in?

options.label: A
options.text: The total number of people living in a country

options.label: B
options.text: The total GDP divided by the number of people living in that country

options.label: C
options.text: The total value of goods and services produced in a country

options.label: D
options.text: The total value of exports and imports in a country

options.label: B
options.text: It doesn't take into account what a country produces or who has access to it

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: Wages stopped keeping pace with GDP growth

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: Because it lays out all the factors a single number obscures

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is more widely used

title: What happens to your body at the top of Mount Everest - Andrew Lovering

multiple-choice.question: At an altitude of 8,848 meters, what percentage of barometric pressure is present compared to sea level?
What happens to the oxygen levels in the air as altitude increases?
What is the primary function of hemoglobin in red blood cells?

What is the immediate response of the body to high altitudes, triggered by carotid chemoreceptors in the neck?

options.label: C
options.text: No change in heart rate and breathing

multiple-choice.question: What adaptation occurs in the blood within the first few days above 1,500 meters?

options.label: C
options.text: Increase in white blood cell count

options.label: D
options.text: Decrease in red blood cell count

multiple-choice.question: What is the process called when breathing increases further after several weeks of acclimatization?
What condition can occur in the brain at altitudes above 3,500 meters due to increased pressure and blood vessel leakage?
What genetic advantage do some Tibetans and South Americans have that can prevent minor altitude sickness?

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: What have climbers over the last century proved about human adaptation to high altitudes?

options.label: B
options.text: That humans can adapt to high altitudes, but only up to a certain point

options.label: C
options.text: That humans can go higher than scientists ever thought possible

options.label: D

title: Why can parrots talk? - Grace Smith-Vidaurre and Tim Wright

multiple-choice.question: What happened to a parrot that went missing in 2010 and was reunited with its owner four years later?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The parrot had gained a new language.

options.label: C
options.text: The parrot had lost its British accent and was speaking in Spanish.

multiple-choice.question: Which animals, apart from humans, are capable of producing human speech?

options.label: B
options.text: To communicate with each other for mating, territorial displays, and group movements.

options.label: D
options.text: To alert other parrots to danger.

multiple-choice.question: How do Monk parakeets use contact calls to interact with each other?

options.label: A
options.text: They use a single, universal contact call.

options.label: B
options.text: They have individualized contact calls to help them stand out.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: They do not use contact calls at all.

multiple-choice.question: What organ do parrots use to produce sound, unlike humans who use their larynx?

options.label: B

options.label: A
options.text: To form social bonds with their owners.

options.label: C
options.text: To learn new words and phrases.

options.label: D
options.text: To mimic human speech without understanding its meaning.

options.label: B
options.text: Asking for a treat and then refusing it.

options.label: C
options.text: Saying "goodnight" at the end of the day.

multiple-choice.question: What is a major threat to wild parrot populations, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Habitat destruction due to natural disasters.

options.label: B
options.text: Poaching and pet trading, as well as habitat loss due to deforestation.

options.label: C
options.text: Climate change and its effects on food availability.

options.label: D
options.text: Human-parrot conflict due to crop damage.
